questions.text: When you try to start the car, what happens?
questions.intuition: Clicking means starter engaging but weak battery; cranking but no start means fuel or spark issue.

questions.text: Do the dashboard/interior lights seem dim or flickering?
questions.intuition: Dim lights confirm battery weakness; normal lights point to starter or connections.

questions.text: How does it crank?
questions.intuition: Slow crank means dying battery; normal speed crank means fuel or ignition problem.

questions.text: Do ANY lights, chimes, or electronics turn on when you try?
questions.intuition: No power at all means dead battery or main power loss; some power means starter or fuel issue.

questions.text: Did this start suddenly, or has it been getting worse?
questions.intuition: Sudden failure suggests fuel or immobilizer; gradual degradation suggests sensor or tune issues.

questions.text: Do you see a flashing key/security/immobilizer light?
questions.intuition: Prevents misdiagnosing immobilizer lockout as battery or starter failure.

questions.text: Does your fuel gauge usually read correctly?
questions.intuition: Unreliable gauge increases likelihood of out-of-fuel despite gauge reading.

questions.text: When the car stalls, what are you doing?
questions.intuition: Stalling at idle suggests idle control; under load suggests fuel delivery problem.

questions.text: After it stalls, does it restart easily?
questions.intuition: Immediate restart means idle issue; needs wait time means fuel pressure or heat soak.

questions.text: Does it stall after bumps or turning?
questions.intuition: Motion-triggered stalling points to loose connection or fuel slosh in near-empty tank.

questions.text: Does it stall mostly when coming to a stop?
questions.intuition: Deceleration stalling is classic idle air control valve or throttle body issue.

questions.text: What happens when you shift into drive and press the gas?
questions.intuition: No movement means transmission not engaging; high RPM but slow movement means slipping clutches.

questions.text: When you press the gas, how does the engine respond?
questions.intuition: Normal RPM rise but no movement confirms transmission issue; no RPM means engine power problem.

questions.text: If you put it in neutral on a flat surface, does it roll freely?
questions.intuition: Resistance while rolling means seized caliper or parking brake; free roll confirms transmission fault.

questions.text: Do you see any of these warnings right now?
questions.intuition: Active warnings narrow down which system is reporting a fault to the computer.

questions.text: When do you mostly hear the noise?
questions.intuition: Braking noise means brake system; turning means CV joint or bearing; speed-dependent means wheel related.

questions.text: Does the noise change more with engine RPM or vehicle speed?
questions.intuition: RPM-dependent means engine or accessories; speed-dependent means wheels, tires, or bearings.

questions.text: How would you describe the pitch?
questions.intuition: High pitch suggests metal-on-metal or bearing; low rumble suggests tire or worn bushing.

questions.text: Is it constant or rhythmic?
questions.intuition: Rhythmic thumping with wheel rotation means tire or wheel defect; constant means bearing or brake drag.

questions.text: If you shift to neutral while moving, does the noise change?
questions.intuition: Noise stops in neutral means drivetrain issue; persists means wheel, tire, or bearing.

questions.text: Which warning best matches what you see?
questions.intuition: Different lights indicate different systems: oil pressure is critical, check engine varies widely.

questions.text: Is the light flashing or steady?
questions.intuition: Flashing check engine means active misfire causing catalyst damage; steady means stored code only.

questions.text: Did it appear suddenly, or has it been on for a while?
questions.intuition: Sudden onset suggests recent failure; long-standing suggests minor issue or ignored problem.

questions.text: When do you mostly feel the vibration?
questions.intuition: Highway speed means wheel balance or alignment; braking means warped rotor.

questions.text: Where do you mostly feel it?
questions.intuition: Steering wheel means front wheels or brakes; seat means rear wheels or driveline.

questions.text: Does it change noticeably with light braking?
questions.intuition: Changes with braking confirms brake rotor warp or pad issue rather than wheel balance.

questions.text: Does it feel like the car is bouncing or hopping at speed?
questions.intuition: Hopping indicates out-of-round tire or separated belt rather than just imbalance.

questions.text: What describes your brake issue best?
questions.intuition: Soft pedal means hydraulic leak; noise means wear; long stopping means pad wear or fade.

questions.text: When does the noise occur?
questions.intuition: Only when pressing means pad wear; also when released means caliper dragging or stuck.

questions.text: Is stopping distance longer than normal?
questions.intuition: Increased stopping distance with soft pedal confirms hydraulic failure rather than just air in lines.

questions.text: Does the car pull to one side when braking?
questions.intuition: Pulling means uneven brake force from seized caliper, contaminated pad, or air in one line.

questions.text: Do you notice a hot/burning smell after a short drive?
questions.intuition: Hot smell after short drive confirms caliper is dragging and overheating that wheel.

questions.text: What best matches your tire problem?
questions.intuition: Visible flat is obvious; TPMS only means slow leak; thumping means structural damage.

questions.text: Does the car pull strongly to one side while driving?
questions.intuition: Strong pull with tire issue means severely underinflated tire creating drag.

questions.text: How does the tire lose air?
questions.intuition: Fast loss means puncture or damaged valve; slow means nail, bead leak, or rim crack.

questions.text: What best describes the HVAC issue?
questions.intuition: No heat means coolant flow or thermostat; smell means leak; AC not cooling means refrigerant.

questions.text: Does the engine reach normal temperature?
questions.intuition: Never reaching temp means stuck-open thermostat; normal temp means heater core or blend door issue.

questions.text: Does air blow strongly from the vents?
questions.intuition: No airflow means blower motor dead; weak means resistor or cabin filter; strong means heater core.

questions.text: Do you notice a sweet/coolant-like smell?
questions.intuition: Sweet smell means coolant leaking from heater core inside dash or external leak getting sucked in.

questions.text: Has coolant been low recently?
questions.intuition: Needing frequent top-offs confirms leak rather than just low coolant from initial fill.

questions.text: What smell do you notice from the vents?
questions.intuition: Exhaust means dangerous leak into cabin; fuel means injector leak; sweet means coolant leak.

questions.text: Where do you notice it most?
questions.intuition: Outside only means external leak; in cabin means entering through vents or firewall breach.

questions.text: Does the smell change when recirculation is ON?
questions.intuition: Better with recirc means external fumes coming in; worse means internal source like heater core.

questions.text: Does it happen only when heat is ON?
questions.intuition: Only with heat means heater core specific; all the time means exhaust or external leak.

questions.text: When A/C is ON, what best describes it?
questions.intuition: Blows warm means no refrigerant or compressor not engaging; weak means airflow restriction.

questions.text: When does HVAC fail most often?
questions.intuition: Temperature-dependent failure suggests expansion/contraction issue with actuator or wiring connection.

questions.text: Does fan speed change when adjusted?
questions.intuition: No speed change means blower motor or resistor dead; changes mean blend door or mode door issue.

questions.text: Any clicking/actuator noise behind the dash?
questions.intuition: Clicking means blend door actuator trying to move but stuck or stripped gear.
